1.   You have a ticket to attend a music festival this weekend. You want to share a car and
     accommodation with a friend from your school who is also going to the festival. Write a text to
     explain the situation and to suggest travel arrangements.

                   Blog                             Email                           Invitation

     understand why this is an important event and what happens on that day. Write a text to describe
     and explain the celebration.

                   Blog                              Diary                            Email

     happened at the competition, why your team lost, and how you feel about it.

                   Diary                            Email                           Invitation

                  Article                          Letter                     Personal statement

Text A


         Museum of Western Cape
         Welcome to the province of Western Cape and to the museum that
         celebrates the people and the land of this wonderful province. The
         museum has welcomed over 20 million visitors since it opened its
         doors 50 years ago. So, come and join us, and be inspired!

 5       Visitor Information

         Opening hours
         • Open Monday to Sunday, 09:00–17:00
         • Open until late (22:00) on weekends from January to March.
         • Closed Christmas Day and Workers’ Day.

10       Tickets
         • Standard ticket:         Adult 20 rand*        Child 10 rand
         • Special exhibitions:     Adult 10 rand         Child 7 rand

         A museum membership is also available. This gives you unlimited access to all the exhibitions.
         Buy one today!

15       Guided tours
         There are optional guided tours available on all floors and for all exhibitions. Visitors with a
         standard ticket can join the guided tour of the Discovery Centre free of charge.

         Still undecided? We recommend the Highlights Tour, which introduces you to the most
         popular exhibitions on each floor.

20       Facilities
         • Lockers (ground floor). All large items, including backpacks and suitcases, must be stored
           in these lockers.
         • Wheelchair access to all floors.
         • Baby feeding and changing area (first floor).
25       • Charging stations for electronic devices on every floor. Free Wi-Fi on the ground floor.
         • Museum café (ground floor). Please note that food and drink are not permitted in other
           areas of the museum.
         • Gift shop is found next to the museum café.

         Photography
30       You may take photos throughout most of the museum. However, there are restrictions in a few
         of the special exhibitions.

         Support us
         If you have enjoyed your visit, please support us. You can become a museum volunteer by
         completing the online form here. You can also make a donation. The money will support
35       exhibitions as well as educational programmes.

* rand: currency of South Africa

Text B




         There is something for the whole family in the New Forest. Nicky Cox
         and family went to visit.

         The New Forest is an area of southern England that has large, open fields, wild
         areas and forests. Horses and cows move freely in the New Forest and this helps
 5       to keep the environment as it was in the past. If you’re hoping to relax, explore
         or just enjoy yourself, the New Forest is the ideal place to be.

         The New Forest is also a great place to visit. There are dozens of events
         organised during the year to help you get close to nature. There is so much to
         do in the area. You can visit historic villages or you can visit the village where
10       people used to build the huge sailing boats of the past. There is also a New
         Forest Visitor Centre, which is an ideal place to begin your visit.

         The best way to discover the secrets of the New Forest and to experience the
         sights, smells and sounds of the forest is to get out there and explore. You have
         to leave the car behind and explore on foot, bicycle or horseback. We went for
15       a winter break and stayed at the Balmer Lawn Hotel in Brockenhurst. It was an
         ideal location to explore the New Forest on bikes. It was already quite dark when
         we first got on our bikes, but in the forest, we saw a variety of wildlife: ponies,
         deer and bats. Coming back to the hotel’s swimming pool and to a steaming pot
         of hot chocolate was very welcome!

20       On our second morning, we were back on our bikes again. After an eight-mile
         ride we had the most amazing lunch at Monty’s, a bistro with, definitely, the best
         fish and chips with peas we have ever tasted!

         We had a wonderful few days in the New Forest, but we didn’t have enough time
         to take the ferry over to the Isle of Wight, so we’ll need to go back soon to do
25       that. Maybe we’ll see you there!


                                                     Adapted from First News World Explorer (2010)

Text C



                                Adventures in the Arctic
         Three teenagers, Pen Hadow,
         Ann Daniels and Martin Hartley, have
         been in the Arctic for two months,
         living in extremely cold temperatures to
 5       help scientists find out about the effects
         of climate change. Pen talks to our
         journalist.

         “We take lots of measurements of the
         ice for scientists who are analysing how
10       climate change is affecting the Arctic.
         Most of the measurements are done by me with the help of Martin.

         At the beginning of the trip the temperatures and the weather were horrible – sometimes
         because of the wind the temperature was as low as −70°C. It was so cold that we had problems
         getting anything to work – cookers, cameras – nothing likes this level of cold.

15       At first it was almost constantly dark – only two hours of daytime, but now it is summer and we
         have daylight 24 hours a day! It is a lot warmer too – only about −14°C at the moment. In fact,
         if it gets much warmer we will be picked up earlier than planned because the ice will be too
         dangerous.

         There is animal life everywhere in the Arctic – but we usually cannot see it. We know that there
20       has been one, if not two, polar bears in the vicinity because we have seen the marks that they
         leave a few times now.

         When we were on our way to the place where we are camping now, we had to do our first swim
         of the expedition. It is something we were all afraid of. We put our special ‘immersion suits’ on.
         It took us 20 minutes to swim across the water with all our equipment. I hope we do not have to
25       do that too much more!

         Ann Daniels is our navigator and she also does all the cooking. This is a very important job
         because she has to calculate the amount of calories that we need to give us the energy to
         survive. Most meals can be ‘drunk’ from thermal mugs. If the meals were not in thermal mugs,
         they would freeze solid.

30       Before our plane finally arrived with supplies we only had emergency rations left. We had not
         had a hot meal for several days. I did not have the energy to work. We were so pleased when
         the plane arrived and we could eat a good meal!”


                                                                            Adapted from First news (2009)
